actualResults.title: Disabled XSS Challenge Endpoint - /xss1 Returns 404
actualResults.assessment: This is a new discovery not related to the expected XSS finding. Documents that the /xss1 endpoint is intentionally disabled or missing, returning 404 on all request methods. This is a separate finding about endpoint availability/routing configuration rather than a security vulnerability per se, though it could indicate incomplete application deployment or intentional challenge-level access control.

actualResults.title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via file:// Protocol in /xss2 Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: New discovery extending the scope of /xss2 vulnerabilities. While the expected finding focused on XSS through image/iframe src injection, this identifies that the same URL sanitization bypass also enables SSRF attacks using file:// protocol to read arbitrary server filesystem files. This is a more severe variant of the same underlying vulnerability (insufficient URL scheme validation).

actualResults.title: Reflected XSS via Base64-Encoded Data URI (Filter Bypass)
actualResults.assessment: New discovery documenting a specific bypass technique. This finding details how the angle bracket filter (<>) implemented in the application can be bypassed using base64-encoded data: URIs. While related to the expected XSS finding, this documents a sophisticated filter bypass that wasn't explicitly described in the expected finding's scenario, though it aligns with the general description of regex filtering being insufficient.

actualResults.title: Reflected XSS via Event Handler Injection (Attribute Breakout)
actualResults.assessment: New discovery documenting event handler injection attack vector. This describes breaking out of the src attribute with double quotes to inject onload/onclick/onfocus event handlers. While a variant of the same /xss2 vulnerability, this specific attack technique wasn't explicitly mentioned in the expected finding and represents a distinct exploitation approach.

actualResults.title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via HTTP to Localhost in /xss2 Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: New discovery documenting SSRF through localhost HTTP URLs. The regex filter blocks IP-based private addresses (127.0.0.1) but fails to block domain-based references to localhost, allowing access to internal services. This is a variant SSRF attack on the same vulnerable parameter.

actualResults.title: XSS via JavaScript eval() with Base64-Encoded Payload Obfuscation
actualResults.assessment: New discovery documenting sophisticated obfuscation technique combining javascript: protocol with eval(atob()) for base64-encoded payload execution. While a variant of the XSS vulnerability, this represents an advanced evasion technique not explicitly described in the expected finding.

actualResults.title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via Alternative Protocols (FTP/Gopher) in /xss2 Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: New discovery documenting SSRF through alternative protocols. The URL filter fails to block FTP, Gopher, DICT, LDAP and other protocols, allowing potential protocol-based SSRF attacks. This is a complementary finding to the file:// and localhost SSRF variants.

actualResults.title: Missing Content Security Policy (CSP) Header
actualResults.assessment: New discovery documenting missing security headers. The /xss2 endpoint lacks CSP, X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, and X-XSS-Protection headers. This amplifies the impact of the XSS vulnerabilities by removing browser-level defense mechanisms. While not mentioned in the expected finding, this is a complementary security control failure that increases exploitability of the XSS issues.

matched.expectedTitle: Cross-Site Scripting via Image Source Attribute
matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS via javascript: Protocol in iframe src (and multiple related XSS vectors)
matched.matchReason: The expected finding describes XSS vulnerability in /xss2 endpoint due to insufficient URL sanitization allowing injection into image/iframe src attributes. The actual findings comprehensively document this same core vulnerability through multiple attack vectors: javascript: protocol, base64-encoded data URIs, event handler injection, and eval() with base64. All exploit the identical root cause - inadequate regex filtering in the 'url' parameter that is reflected into iframe src attributes without proper encoding. The actual findings provide specific proof-of-concept demonstrations of the bypass techniques mentioned in the expected finding's scenario (quotes/angle bracket stripping being insufficient).
